description: From Middle English woodeman, wodeman, from Old English wudemann, wudumann (“woodman”), equivalent to wood +‎ -man.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Someone who hunts animals in a wood, hunter, huntsman.
examples: How daintily, and cunningly you drive me
Up like a Deere to’th toyle, yet I may leape it,

entries.meaning: Someone who cuts down trees or cuts and sells wood, lumberjack, woodcutter.
examples: As thro’ the shrilling Vale, or Mountain Ground,
The Labours of the Woodman’s Axe resound;
Blows following Blows are heard re-echoing wide,
While crackling Forests fall on ev’ry side.
Thus echo’d all the Fields with loud Alarms,
So fell the Warriors, and so rung their Arms.

entries.meaning: Someone who lives in the wood and manages it; a woodsman; (by extension) someone who spends time in the woods and has a strong familiarity with that environment.
examples: Our walk was far among the ancient trees:
There was no road, nor any wood-man’s path,
But the thick umbrage, checking the wild growth

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Someone who lives in the woods and is considered to be uncivilized or barbaric, a savage.
examples: The prying Fauns and Woodmen dark
And prick-ear’d Satyrs her did mark,

entries.meaning: Someone who makes things from wood.
